Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) for FY 2013 in Singapore
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Dawn Catherine Sweeney Ruth of the University at Buffalo to conduct a research project in Geosciences during the summer of 2013 at Nanyang Technological University in Singapore. The project title is "Relating Rock Chemistry and Earthquake Data to Improve Volcano Monitoring Efforts." The host scientist(s) is Dr. Fidel Costa Rodriguez.

This project assesses if the timing of magma movement is related to the timing of earthquakes and ground deformation that occur prior to an eruption, with the ultimate goal of improving volcano monitoring efforts. The migration of magmas from depth is understood as a key eruption-triggering process. Determining the timing of earthquakes and ground deformation is straightforward as the instruments used record a time stamp at the onset of movement. Olivine crystals collected from the products of an eruption are being used to estimate the timing of actual magma movement. When crystals form, the distribution of elements is set. However, this distribution can be affected by subjecting the crystals to new environmental conditions, such as changing the temperature through magma movement. Since changes in elemental distribution in olivine crystals is well understood, comparison of the observed elemental distributions with computer models can be used to estimate the time elapsed since magma movement. Moreover, if the eruption date is known, the approach provides an estimate of when magma movement occurred. If magma movement can be definitively dated and linked to specific seismic signals, then a more process-based approach to volcanic monitoring will likely improve interpretation of geophysical signals at volcanoes.

Broader impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce. Successful completion of the project will expand the Fellow's analytical geochemistry toolkit which will provide the basis for a short course in analytical geochemistry techniques to be given at the Fellow's home institution. Furthermore, the findings of this project will be presented at an international conference and the Fellow will submit the detailed findings to a peer-reviewed journal.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Intellectual Merit of the research project was to assess if the timing of magma movement is related to the timing of earthquakes and ground deformation that occur prior to an eruption, with the ultimate goal of improving volcano monitoring efforts.  Magma migration from depth is considered a key eruption triggering process. While earthquakes and ground deformation signals are recorded in real time, often only after the fact are they recognized as being related to the onset of magma movement. Olivine crystals collected from the products of the 2008 eruption of Llaima volcano, Chile and were used to estimate the timing of actual magma movement. This was achieved first by measuring the current distribution of elements within crystals. The distribution of elements is set when crystals form. However, the distribution can change by moving the crystal to new environmental conditions, such as changing the temperature or composition through magma movement and mixing. These results were compared with computer models to estimate the time elapsed since magma movement. In this project, twelve different crystals were analyzed and produced a range of times that suggest magma movement ~470 to 56 days prior to the eruption. There are two clusters of 3 or more crystals with similar migration timing found within this dataset: (1) 200-240 days and (2) 100-140 days. Because the eruption date is known, it is possible to compare these clusters to seismic signals. The 200-240 day cluster overlaps with the onset of ground deformation and two days of elevated earthquake activity. Likewise, the 100-140 day cluster also overlaps with two days of elevated earthquake activity. These results highlight the importance of linking geophysical signals and magmatic processes, if possible.  With more studies such as this, a more process-based approach to volcanic monitoring will be achieved and will likely improve interpretation of geophysical signals at volcanoes.

The results of this project indicate that the integration of monitoring data related to eruption unrest with the basic information on processes derived from erupted crystals is possible. Continued integration at Llaima and integration at other volcanic centers will lead to improved forecasting of volcanic eruptions and hazard mitigation efforts. In line with the Broader Impacts outlined by the NSF, this project helped facilitate an international collaborative relationship between the host mentor and institution, and the principal investigator, based on the common interest of understanding the magmatic processes related to eruptive behavior. This international collaboration directly meets the NSF goal to develop such collaborations early in the career of its scientists. Finally, the project broadened the participation of an underrepresented group within the STEM fields. Through the work completed during this research, the principal investigator has received training on element diffusion in magmatic crystals, and electron backscatter diffraction. These skills expand the principal investigator’s toolkit and will provide the basis for courses on analytical geochemistry techniques in the future.
